verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, “Go to Pharaoh and say to him, ‘This is what the LORD, the God of the Hebrews, says: Let my people go, so that they may serve me.’”
verses.comment: Note the repeated demand for Israel's freedom is connected to worship. Service to God is more than departure; it is entrance into true worship. In typology, Israel's call from Egypt foreshadows spiritual deliverance offered through Christ (see Matt. 2:15).

verses.text: If you refuse to let them go and continue to hold them,
verses.comment: Pharaoh’s continued hardness is the backdrop for escalating judgment. A spiritual reading sees the stubbornness as an image of the resistance of the unredeemed heart before grace.

verses.text: then the hand of the LORD will fall with a severe plague upon your livestock in the field—on the horses, donkeys, camels, herds, and flocks.
verses.comment: God’s judgment is expansive, touching every aspect of Egyptian agriculture. The ‘hand of the LORD’ here represents God’s power and justice, echoed in various passages describing divine intervention (see 2 Sam. 5:6).

verses.text: But the LORD will make a distinction between the livestock of Israel and the livestock of Egypt, so that nothing belonging to the Israelites will die.’”
verses.comment: This separation stresses God’s covenantal protection for His people, a theme developed in later salvation history. It foreshadows the spiritual separation of believers from the world through divine grace.

verses.text: The LORD set a specific time, saying, “Tomorrow the LORD will do this in the land.”
verses.comment: God’s control over time and events is emphasized in this declaration. This affirms His sovereignty—a theme found throughout scripture.

verses.text: The next day the LORD did this: all the livestock of Egypt died, but not one of the livestock belonging to the Israelites died.
verses.comment: God’s exact fulfillment underscores His reliability and justice. This miraculous distinction again reflects divine election and foreknowledge.

verses.text: Pharaoh sent and found that not even one of the Israelites’ livestock had died. Yet Pharaoh’s heart remained hard, and he did not let the people go.
verses.comment: Despite clear proofs, Pharaoh resists. The motif of hardened hearts foreshadows humanity's need for divine intervention to truly open hearts for conversion and worship (see Ezek. 36:26).

verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses and Aaron, “Take handfuls of soot from a furnace, and let Moses toss it into the air in the presence of Pharaoh.”
verses.comment: The soot, likely symbolic of suffering and oppression, becomes the instrument of judgment, recalling how God can transform suffering into redemptive action (see Rom. 8:18).

verses.text: It will become fine dust over all the land of Egypt, and will become boils breaking out with sores on men and animals throughout Egypt.”
verses.comment: Physical affliction now comes directly, fulfilling curses outlined in Deuteronomy. Suffering highlights the seriousness of spiritual rebellion, and points to the need for healing and restoration available through God.

verses.text: So they took soot from the furnace and stood before Pharaoh. Moses threw it into the air, and boils broke out with sores on both men and animals.
verses.comment: Here the action exactly fulfills God’s words. Replication and fulfillment is a pattern in divine revelation, strengthening belief in prophecy and promise.

verses.text: The magicians could not stand before Moses because of the boils, for the boils were on the magicians and all the Egyptians.
verses.comment: Egyptian magic, once able to imitate miracles, now fails utterly before divine judgment, foreshadowing how human means cannot achieve ultimate spiritual healing outside of God’s supernatural power.

verses.text: But the LORD hardened Pharaoh’s heart, and he did not listen to them, just as the LORD had spoken to Moses.
verses.comment: The hardening of Pharaoh’s heart is a mystery involving both divine sovereignty and human responsibility, a tension that invites deeper contemplation about grace and free will.

verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, “Rise early in the morning and present yourself to Pharaoh and say to him, ‘This is what the LORD, the God of the Hebrews, says: Let my people go, that they may serve me.
verses.comment: Repeating His call, God emphasizes the core reason for deliverance: worship and service. The repeated summons for worship continues as a thread through God's relationship with humanity, fulfilled ultimately in Christ's call to worship in spirit and truth.

verses.text: For this time I will send all my plagues against you, your servants, and your people, so you may know that there is none like me in all the earth.
verses.comment: Divine uniqueness is asserted; this exclusivity prefigures biblical monotheism, affirmed in both Old and New Testament revelation.

verses.text: If I had stretched out my hand and struck you and your people with pestilence, you would have been wiped off the earth.
verses.comment: God reminds Pharaoh of His power and mercy. Though judgment is strong, divine patience allows for repentance—a message echoed by Christ (see Luke 13:3).

verses.text: But for this reason I have allowed you to remain: to show you my power, and that my name may be declared throughout all the earth.
verses.comment: The purpose of Pharaoh's endurance is ultimately God’s glory and universal knowledge of His name, a motif later fulfilled in the worldwide proclamation of the Gospel.

verses.text: You still exalt yourself against my people and do not let them go.
verses.comment: Pharaoh’s pride is made explicit, reminiscent of the fall narratives connected to pride, which is consistently condemned in biblical revelation.

verses.text: Behold, tomorrow at this time I will cause a very severe hail to fall, such as has never been seen in Egypt from the day it was founded until now.
verses.comment: Catastrophic hail accentuates the escalation of judgment. In biblical typology, God's command of nature is a demonstration of His supremacy over all creation.

verses.text: Now therefore, send and gather your livestock and all that you have in the field to safety. Every person or animal in the field and not brought home will die when the hail falls on them.”
verses.comment: A warning is given before judgment. God’s mercy appears even in the midst of justice: preservation is offered to those who heed.

verses.text: Those among Pharaoh’s officials who feared the word of the LORD hurried to bring their servants and animals inside.
verses.comment: Response to God’s warning splits Egyptians: some heed, some ignore. This division foreshadows response to revelation throughout salvation history.

verses.text: But those who did not pay attention to the word of the LORD left their servants and livestock in the field.
verses.comment: Obedience and its consequences are delineated here, a principle recurring in New Testament teaching on faith and works.

verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, “Stretch out your hand toward heaven, so that hail may fall in all the land of Egypt—on man, animal, and every plant in the fields of Egypt.”
verses.comment: Moses acts as God’s mediator. The hand lifted toward heaven has connotations of priestly intercession, which increases in importance through biblical history.

verses.text: So Moses stretched out his staff toward heaven, and the LORD sent thunder and hail, and fire ran down to the earth. The LORD rained hail on the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: Thunder, hail, and fire signal God’s lordship over the elements. Signs and wonders serve as both literal punishment and spiritual signposts to His omnipotence.

verses.text: There was hail and fire flashing in the midst of the hail, very severe—the like of which had never occurred in all the land of Egypt since its beginning.
verses.comment: Nature’s disturbance reinforces the ‘never before’ motif, emphasizing the extraordinary intervention of God in history.

verses.text: The hail struck down everything in the fields—both man and beast—throughout the land of Egypt. It shattered every plant and broke every tree in the field.
verses.comment: Judgment extends to all creation, reflecting the far-reaching effects of sin described in Genesis and restored only in redemption.

verses.text: But in the land of Goshen, where the Israelites lived, there was no hail.
verses.comment: God’s protective presence in Goshen signals His faithfulness to His covenant people. Such signs underscore the power of belonging to God’s family and receiving His special care.

verses.text: Then Pharaoh sent for Moses and Aaron, and said, “This time I have sinned. The LORD is righteous, and I and my people are wicked.”
verses.comment: Pharaoh’s confession is striking, though incomplete. He acknowledges God’s justice—an important moment showing that repentance is possible even for the powerful, though Scripture suggests it must be deeper than mere words.

verses.text: Plead with the LORD to end the thunder and hail, and I will let you go; you do not need to stay any longer.”
verses.comment: Pharaoh asks for intercession, recognizing Moses as a true mediator. Moses’ willingness to intercede points to the necessity of a faithful intermediary and ultimately the need of one who stands between God and humanity.

verses.text: Moses said to him, “When I leave the city, I will stretch out my hands to the LORD. The thunder will stop, and there will be no more hail, so that you may know that the earth belongs to the LORD.
verses.comment: Moses' prayerful posture—hands extended—foreshadows later traditions of liturgical prayer and priestly intercession. The claim that ‘the earth is the LORD's’ is a foundational doctrine about God's universal sovereignty.

verses.text: But as for you and your servants, I know that you do not yet fear the LORD God.
verses.comment: True fear of God goes beyond expedient words. Authentic worship and reverence are perennial themes in spiritual life.

verses.text: The flax and barley were destroyed, since the barley was in the ear and the flax in bud.
verses.comment: The verse notes agricultural timing, indicating the historical context and totality of loss—emphasizing the integrated relationship of humanity and creation under divine judgment.

verses.text: But the wheat and spelt were not destroyed, since they ripen later.
verses.comment: A detail that affirms the literal historical nature of the narrative, underscoring God’s precision and restraint even in judgment.

verses.text: Then Moses left Pharaoh and went out of the city, and he stretched out his hands to the LORD. The thunder and hail ceased, and the rain stopped pouring upon the earth.
verses.comment: Moses' prayer brings deliverance. The effectiveness of intercessory prayer is shown repeatedly in Scripture, and foreshadows the ongoing role of intercessors in biblical tradition.

verses.text: But when Pharaoh saw that the rain, hail, and thunder had stopped, he sinned again and hardened his heart—he and his officials.
verses.comment: Pharaoh’s repeated sin after relief demonstrates the danger of superficial repentance and the need for a deeper conversion of heart. This motif recurs in the lives of biblical figures and is addressed by Christ in the Gospels.

verses.text: So Pharaoh’s heart was hardened, and he did not let the Israelites go, just as the LORD had spoken through Moses.
verses.comment: The narrative closes with God's word fulfilled, encouraging trust in divine promises and warning against persistent resistance to grace—an apt spiritual lesson for all ages.
